head.title: New Yorkers Bike Locally, Think Globally

hedline.hl1: New Yorkers Bike Locally, Think Globally

abstract.p: Robert Jereski letter cites H J Wells in praising New Yorkers who ride bicycles, doing their part to slow global warming; drawing

block.p: ''Global Warming Moves From Impassioned Words to Modest Deeds'' (news article, Nov. 19) reminded me of H. G. Wells's comment that whenever he saw a grown man on a bicycle, he had hope for civilization. Much has changed since Wells's day, but much remains the same. The prestige-bestowing Model T may have become the gas-guzzling sport utility, and the cobblestone streets of the early 20th century may have become the V-8-plagued avenues of our city, but the basic human landscape remains the same.
Despite the fear, vanity and ignorance that pressure many to hide their vulnerability inside several tons of steel, many thoughtful New Yorkers choose self-locomotion above status.

''Global Warming Moves From Impassioned Words to Modest Deeds'' (news article, Nov. 19) reminded me of H. G. Wells's comment that whenever he saw a grown man on a bicycle, he had hope for civilization. Much has changed since Wells's day, but much remains the same. The prestige-bestowing Model T may have become the gas-guzzling sport utility, and the cobblestone streets of the early 20th century may have become the V-8-plagued avenues of our city, but the basic human landscape remains the same.
Despite the fear, vanity and ignorance that pressure many to hide their vulnerability inside several tons of steel, many thoughtful New Yorkers choose self-locomotion above status.
Underserved by the city agencies, these New Yorkers do good deeds with humility and a sense of global civic responsibility, merely by virtue of riding a bicycle.
